page.title: 06THE HATTON ARMS, GRETTON
page.content: The Hatton Arms is one of the oldest buildings in the village, and it got its name from the Lord of the Manor of Gretton at the time it was built in the late sixteenth century, Sir Christopher Hatton. In 1672 the tenancy of the inn was reputedly given to a negro servant of Lord Hatton, by name of James Chappell as a reward for saving his master's life in a fire. James Chappell's death is recorded in the Parish Church in 1732. The Hatton Arms was used as the Manor Court until 1919, when a new system of land registration was brought in by Parliament. Three crown stamps dated 1117 can be found on the beam in the bar, the reason being that in 1117 the trees used for the beams in the inn were felled in the Crown Forest of Rockingham.
